newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Portuguese, South Africa leaders discuss East Timor.
newsitem.headline: Portuguese, South Africa leaders discuss East Timor.

text.p: South African President Nelson Mandela and Portuguese President Jorge Sampaio began talks in Pretoria on Wednesday on the disputed Pacific territory of East Timor.
"They have started the meeting at 11.30 a.m. (0930 GMT)," a foreign affairs official told Reuters.

Sampaio, accompanied by Portugal's Foreign Minister Jaime Gama, arrived on Wednesday at the invitation of Mandela, who is helping U.N. efforts to speed an accord between former colonial ruler Portugal and current ruler Indonesia on the future of East Timor.
Indonesia annexed East Timor two decades ago in a move never recognised by the United Nations.
Mandela met Nobel laureate Jose Ramos Horta, the exiled spokesman for jailed Timor resistance leader Xanana Gusmao, in South Africa last Friday.

Mandela, who also met Gusmao during a recent visit to Indonesia, has said he is not trying to usurp the role of the United Nations, which has been brokering so far unsuccessful talks between Portugal and Indonesia.
Portuguese media reported that during the visit Mandela had asked Indonesia's President Suharto to release Gusmao.
